commentBody: I thought it was interesting and a good challenge.  I can feel the rebus haters misdirected anger bubbling up at a distance.
I'm very old-school, I guess, but I really don't like it when reading the grid left to right gives you gibberish, as occurred here a few times. The trick was very cumbersome.

Wow.  Given all the layers to this theme and that they weave together so seamlessly, this is a work of art as well as a puzzle.  





Et ti. emu.
I felt very glad to have figured out the theme on my own!  I only needed four (or five) cheats, and most importantly, this puzzle was FUN!  Thank you!
Took just under an hour. Tough but fair!
Kudos to the constructor. This was a bit challenging, but oodles of fun.

A delightful romp (for me). 
I got that the magnet answers met their match, 
but I didn't immediately grasp the 108 Across.
Clever theme with fine fill. 
What more could one want from a Sunday?  

Thanks, John!

I admire that a grid like this is even possible, but the huge amount of glue needed to hold it all together was a real minus for me. I counted 38 three-letter entries. I probably spent more time grinding through all those than the themers.

A fun challenge! It took me a while to figure out the trick, initially thinking a rebus might be at play. 

I didn’t pick up on the pairings ABS OF STEEL/ACTION STAR, HOUSE OF GOD/CONGREGANT, GREEN GRASS/PERIWINKLE and NOODLE BOWL/EGG FOO YUNG until I read the column. Excellent!

A cringeworthy entry at 47A (I don’t even want to type it here). 

Nicely done, John.
Too gimmicky. Can we please have a regular crossword next week? Call me a dinosaur, I don't mind.

I liked the construction, appreciated the extra brain tickle on a Sunday. My initial impression was, “Good grief that’s a lot of music and movies clues.” I counted 21 afterwards. Is that a lot? Felt like a lot. YMMV. 

All in all, though, a very enjoyable puzzle, which is how John Kugelman likes to make them.

At least three Naticks here.

CISQO/QUANTA (had a C at the crossing)
CELIA/EPPS (tried I and E, but other stuff was wrong)
DAEMONS/TROI (O fit best, but tried E too)

Couldn't work out the last yeah because I didn't consider Q before O to be possible.

ORTEGA/REB and STE/SALERNO were also pretty rough, but I guessed those both right with a relatively high degree of confidence
I picked up the theme immediately, but made a serious booboo with EGGFOYOUNG that took me forever to winkle out.

My review for Diary of a Crossword Fiend: https://crosswordfiend.com I didn’t mention the paired answers like ABS OF STEEL/ACTION STAR because I didn’t notice it except in that instance. I’m not sure that GREEN GRASS/PERIWINKLE is that great a pair, anyway.

Captivating puzzle.

Boy, I went through so many things that Jason Momoa has, from ArmOFSTEEL to AssOFSTEEL (never seen it, but I'm pretty sure it is), to finally ABSOFSTEEL.

And that was just one entry.  I don't know how many times I had to work and rework answers until they finally fit.  10D went through some iterations, and UPVOTE had a complicated history, too.

It would be cool to have an accounting of every keystroke one makes in a puzzle, to measure things like "how many times did each square change", and the "maximum time between any two entries that are correct".

I enjoyed it right up until the inevitable flyspecking that I needed.  

GLAMAZON is very clever.

If there is really animal magnetism, it conjures up some funny images:
Momoa with his abs of steel, struggling with a bunch of eels.
Tough guy Stallone battling with a bunch of rats.
Churchgoer, desperate to sit still while tormented by ants.
You-know-who making a total mess of the green grass.
Not to be outdone, the elk destroying the periwinkle.
The owl and gnu sharing a sloppy meal together, noodles and egg foo yung respectively.

All in all, quite a mess! (Not the puzzle itself of course)

Never heard of fanfic or glamazon or someone named sisqo -is that a real person? and there were a few other iffy fills but nonetheless a brilliant construction. Bravo. 
But sheesh, perhaps this should have been a smaller puzzle on Thursday?

FRENCH OPENS was timely, considering that the finals were/are this weekend. 

I had fun solving this, though hyphens always alarm me at first. And any puzzle that reminds me of ANSEL Adams is okay by me.

I finished this challenge and thank you for it. One problem though - it said I had something wrong, but nothing was marked wrong.  I went to your answer key and compared all, and mine was perfect. This is the first time in a ridiculous number of years that this has happened to me!  Any ideas?

Maybe we can't build BANANAS in the U.S., but I know I have GO(ne)BANANAS for this second super fun John Kugelman puzzle in the last week or so!  I knew it would be so much fun when I opened it and looked at the grid, and I was not disappointed. 

But now I'm going to LAM it because my husband usually has to work away from home on Saturday nights, but not tonight!  Yayyy!!!

When I first saw STEEL being bent by the magnet and then RATS I thought we’d have a metal on one side and an animal on the other which would have been cool (but  likely unrealistic). When I discovered that both sides were three letter animals I was a little underwhelmed. But then I saw that the sides related to each other and that sold me, that was quite an accomplishment. Also, did anyone notice IRON right in the middle of the grid? Wonder if that was deliberate.
Thought his alternatives were great too especially ROCKY BALBOA and APOLLO CREED.
Last comment—I guess I am going to have to resign myself that LAM is a verb, although I am going kicking and screaming.
Thanks, John Kugelman. This is the first Sunday theme I have ever picked up on at the first turn, and also the first Sunday theme in a while I picked up before the column. Most enjoyable.
Can someone explain OBI and ETA, merci
A fine and fun Sunday IMHO. Took a little bit to get the trick, but then things fell into place. I'm glad you stuck with the idea and got it finished, John.
SHEESH is an apt response to much of the fill in this one.
Maybe I’m a snob, but BATTLEROYALES just doesn’t look right.

I was really hoping the animal magnetism would lead to the male and female of the same animal like sow to boar, or cow to bull, etc. I don’t really see how an eel and a rat, or an ant and a dog, are attracted to each other.

Pretty clever puzzle.  Dashed clues always befuddle me, at least for a time.  Even with the revealer it took me some time to figure out the magnetic wrinkle.  The puzzle gets bonus points for introducing me to GLAMAZON.
Is the grid a visual representation of Magneto?
Nope, not gonna do it. I just don't have the patience. I'm grouchy enough that I might throw my computer through a window, and I don't want to deal with the repairs.

Is it cheating if the light bulb when on when I glanced at the wordplay photo?

Got the Goldstar, but not sure if I truly earned it.

I got hung up on HOUSEOFworship, found dog but not god. Ok, I didn’t get the trick but did see the ones going down and turning right but googled Momoa. 

Otherwise, an amusing challenge for me as I knew very few of the famous people. Took a long time baffled by FRENCH-PENS.  Hmm, 14 pens, no idea.
disturbingly easy sunday.  never got one in under 35 minutes before.  straightforwarder-than-usual-for-a-sunday clues, i think.

49D (REB) and 107D (SISQO) did me in, the former because I didn't know this Yiddish term so I guessed RAB as short for RABBI and the latter because I'm not a fan of this kind of music.  I'm old, 76, and I like the Beatles and Chicago and the Eagles etc. But I got everything else. Foreign language and pop culture did me in. I'm guessing that the puzzle author is young and Jewish.  Am I right?
An "A in German class" is not EIN, it's EINS!
The clueing on this was bad, just gave up in the end.  Disappointing Sunday puzzle.

I'm not sure what to say about this one. It wasn't all that difficult (app says 36 minutes under my average), and the trick was clever enough but a bunch of fills were just ... unsatisfying. 

IPS? Computers don't each have an IP (Internet Protocol), they each have an Internet Protocol Address. So "Computer addresses, for short" should be IPAS. (If the clue had been singular, and the answer was IPA, I could live with that. I still wouldn't be happy, but I could live with it).

And as others have pointed out BATTLEROYALES doesn't "feel" right. Merriam Websters prefers it without the final "E", but does have "BATTLE ROYALE" as a variant, so that's OK. But then it goes on to list lots of plurals:
"battles royal or battle royals or battles royale or battle royales" - the last of which was chosen by the constructor. Still, it feels ... unsatisfying.

And there's more. I won't go into detail, but MESH, OMG, OPTOUT (among others) feel forced.

Then there's things like LAS, BEG, DUD, and ROO (among others) that felt like lazy cluing. Almost as if, after getting all the clever fill done, the constructor got tired of thinking and just went with Monday-level clues for the short glue words. 

Such an odd (and unsatisfying) mix.
Bit of a 'meh' puzzle. Unsatisfying in so many little ways, but I can't quite say exactly why.

What a delightful puzzle. I have to admit, I filled in ABSOFSTEEL almost immediately with no crosses and was tickled that it turned out to be right. Someone else mentioned considering asSOFSTEEL and armOFSTEEL, both of which Jason Momoa surely has, but those ABS (and pecs) are permanently burned into my brain since watching GOT.

Another gimme in that section was FANFIC, of which I've read many and even written one myself (about David and Patrick from Schitt's Creek), so I couldn't help checking AO3 (a site that hosts over 15 million fics) for Jason Momoa stories. They're there, but I dare not link to them here because of all the 27A, an entry I found to be very appropriately placed in the puzzle. 

Didn't get the happy finished message right away so had to go back and flyspeck. Man, I wish I was a better speller. I had EGGFuYoUNG and didn't notice it was wrong because ANTONIu is an actual Roman name, and STRATycaster didn't look right but I convinced myself it was. 

It's okay. I FIXedITINPOST. (That's gonna be my new term for going back after I initially think I'm done and cleaning up my mistakes.

Meh, I solved the puzzle easily but the gimmick did nothing to assist me.  I understood the gimmick early on but it really didn’t help me to solve the puzzle.  And it didn’t give me a pleasant aha moment.
Oof — I got the theme really early on but it didn’t do much to help my solve. I just wasn’t on the constructor’s wavelength I guess but this was a _slog_
How can GREEN GRASS be a colourful feature of a lawn? The grass _is_ the lawn, no??

Ok, third time's a charm.  Bare bones.

Concerning the four sets of animals on each side the the magnets.

Opposites attract! Right!

I wrote *two* utterly *hilarious* posts on why the combinations of creatures on each side of the magnets was the other's opposite. 

But apparently, the emus were so amused, in stitches truth be told, they just couldn't let anyone else enjoy them as much as they did.  

So maybe I'll get a chance later, when they've laughed themselves to death.

As someone who has eaten a lot of Chinese food, but not American Chinese food, the "Y" in EGGFOOYUNG was a lesser-spotted self-Natick for me.

I guess most Americans will be familiar enough with the dish for that not to affect them. But nevertheless, I call foul!

Curious if anyone else created their own red herring: I at first saw the magnets as representing the DC Comics logo. 'Abs of steel' seemed to validate this, riffing on 'man of steel'. I was puzzled (ha) when I didn't see any other DC references. I thought Jasan Statham / Stallone would be 'action hero'... but nope. And Spiderman? Wrong universe??  Finally turned out that was a completely wild goose chase...

In the end, this was a very fun puzzle. Well done.
Unless I'm being thick there are 8 unchecked squares in this puzzle which I thought was a big no-no. I found the theme underwhelming and a huge amount of junk fill made this a slog for me
A German grade of A is an "Eins" not "Ein".

I respect the constructor and the difficulty in creating with theme. I could not do it. 

But- I disliked this puzzle. The theme was not witty or funny or interesting. The clues for the fill were mostly boring definitions.  

I like puzzles where I literally smile or laugh when I uncover an entry. 

This one?  No wit. No fun.

Loathed this. It felt like the constructor didn't believe the theme answers were enough of a draw (they were; those were the best clues in the whole puzzle), so they rewrote a bunch of other clues to have the most obtuse, arcane solutions possible. 

Boo.

I’m sorry to say I’m on board with a lot of the gripes in this forum, while also agreeing with the appreciation of the setter for producing such a puzzle. 

I have one gripe to add:

I am getting a bit sick of having one particular brand of American dog food shoved down nut throat… Oreos are bad enough, but at least they are well known outside the US of A. But Alpo??? The clue might as well be “Italian mountain”!

I had to warmly smile when I saw NOODLE in the grid, placed there by a man named Kugelman.  Noodle kugel was a dish my grandmother – who I fiercely loved – made, one of my favorite childhood foods.  The taste, aroma, and the feel of being around my grandmother all evoked by this tiny piece of the puzzle – priceless.
I don't get how manner leads to affect. (5 down)
Well, you can add “JIBE” to the ‘two countries divided by a common language’ list…
Despite its being a PW — by far — for a Sunday puzzle, I did enjoy the battle royale involved for me to get to the end.  I went BONKERS and BERSERK before slipping in BANANAS.
Absofst?

Points:
•	Magnets!  I don’t ever remember seeing images of magnets in a grid.  It’s hard to come up with something new to Crosslandia, and here it is.  Furthermore, these magnets are not just for show; they perform two important functions.  They draw the animals in, and they attract related phrases together (Asian foods, action film actors, ground cover, and church-related).
•	John’s notes in XwordInfo detail how much work went into making this, which took him about a year, involving solidifying the theme concept, coding, culling close to 4,000 phrases, grid design, and making it all work (which was very thorny).  All this for a puzzle that will probably have but one day in the sun.  Strong evidence to me that John is an artist, crafting something beautiful for beauty’s sake, something he hopes others will enjoy.

Well, this was a thing of beauty to me with its intricate theme so comfortably nested the box.  And I sure as heck enjoyed conquering the hills it presented, cracking its riddles, and the discoveries that emerged from it.

This was a jewel, John.  Thank you!
I wonder when the NYT games app will start having the graphics? It’s difficult to use the app without them in a puzzle such as today, w/o seeing the magnets.  🧲
Abandoned.

SO frustrating for me! 
I solved lots of clues but the names and slang - so many I'd never heard of. I revealed one square of lots of them and with auto check and guesses I solved it all in an hour and a half. The theme wasn't too hard really!

Never heard of:
CELIA, EPPS, BORK, ALPO, Jason Momoa, TRIX, HINES, ELECTRO, ORTEGA, GRINER, SWOLE, SIA, the Guinness record, ANA, AVA, LILO, NATS, SISQO, STU, AMPED/stoked,  and the worst NERF - brand name of a ball!

Yet I don't live in a cave!

Nice Sunday outing.  I figured out most of the theme but missed the final layer.  I guess I half noticed some of them, like HOUSE OF GOD and CONGREGANT, but I never put that piece together on my own.  Quite a tour de force, John.  Putting all of those constraints on the puzzle must have made this incredibly difficult to create, so I feel like I let you down a bit.
Enjoyed this puzzle -- but the biggest 'miss' for me was no apparent connection (or attraction) between the animals at the ends of the magnets.

Whew. Tough one for me - took me a long time to finally tumble to half of the trick, and even longer to tumble to the ones that turned the other way. And even then had to stop and ponder a bit over and over again to recall exactly how it was working. But it is really impressive to come up with a new kind of trick like this. A couple of puzzle finds today. First, a Sunday from April 26, 1970 by Alfio Micci with the title: "Musically speaking." A couple of theme clue and answer examples: "Musical creator of monster?" FRANCKENSTEIN "Quinn, Norwegian style?" ZORBATHEGRIEG But most of the others just had a quite straightforward clue with no hint to the trick. e.g: "Telephone sound" BIZETSIGNAL "Child's game" HAYDNGOSEEK "Postal warning" HANDELWITHCARE "___ in air" BRAHMSBURSTING And there were quite a few more. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=4/26/1970&g=25&d=A I'll put the other puzzle in a reply. ....

This was a constructor's crossword, not a solver's.

Too much Slanglish, unknown or rare words, words that appear on the
"new word lists" that constructors use to feed their construction
software programs that force-fit thousands of combinations
and spit out something like this.

BORK. That even makes the Slanglish SNARF(appeared last week) look mainstream.
Both of these words flatline on Google Ngram viewer, especially when compared to SCARF, which is slang itself.

Why do they keep saying "Sunday puzzle is Wednesday/Thursday
difficulty level" when its usually not?

How much of the constructor's original cluing was changed
by NYT editors?

Will these kind of puzzles be the norm when AI takes over
puzzle construction in the near future?

Are these new vocabulary words useful? Or if I tried to use
them in everday speech would I come off as a pretentious
eccentric?

I'm just left with more questions than answers, leaves me with a lot of agita.

This puzzle looks much better in retrospect and I'm really
glad its behind me.
I must say I impressed myself when I finally sussed the SE corner.  oHyEaH where we needed SHEESH was my big hang up (and of course the Thong Song was a total mystery)…
I feel like I’m missing something basic about this puzzle. All of the magnetically attracted animals have extra letters. Do the extras have some significance?

So, is there any connection between the pairs of animals?  When DOG appeared, I thought we might have CAT at the opposite side of the magnet.

And is there any significance to the leftover letters?  If there’s a pattern, it’s not obvious to me.

Random observation: I can't think of a single vegetable oil that comes from a vegetable. Corn is a grain; soybeans are legumes; and grapeseed, safflower, canola, cottonseed, and sunflower oils come from seeds. (Of these listed, only soybean oil and sunflower oil are derived from an edible substance.) Olive oil, avocado oil, and coconut oil are not considered a vegetable oil since they come from fruits. Call me a brainwashed creep--which I am--but I find the term "vegetable oil" misleading.
“Like a mom or dad’s patience” is a great clue.

I finished this fully expecting to get the “something’s amiss” note, because so much seemed to be amiss. TEEL? GANT? DOGF? RASS? ELKN? GNUY? SHEESH. (Notice I left out BOWL and RATS because those are actually words.) I get the theme, but the results seemed a bit inelegant to me.

That said, I’m always happy when my dog makes an appearance in the puzzle. Who’s a good boy? ROO is! (ARF.)

This puzzle was not my thing, for some of the reasons others have mentioned. Mainly, gibberish makes me uncomfortable, and the animals didn’t match each other in any way. Those two things made it not feel clever or artful to me. I love Sunday puzzles. I like a tricky trick. But I just didn’t think this one was interesting. 

Fill and iffy clueing don’t bother me that much anymore but I’ll mention two specific gripes. REB is Yiddish or Aramaic, while the Hebrew would be Rav. Unless the clue was using the word Hebrew to mean Jewish (which would be archaic and a little weird), that was unfair. Second, GLAMAZON rubs me the wrong way. Harumph. I’m going to put this puzzle behind me and enjoy my Sunday.
Incomplete words isn’t tricky, its lazy. I agree with the gibberish words making no sense.

Magnets are neat - useful, fun, and mysterious. Some magnets are very strong, some are weak. But how do they work? Richard Feynman has said* that as intellectually un-satisfying as it may be, there is much about (electro)magnetism that we must (for now) simply accept as a fundamental property of certain arrangements of matter. Mystery and wonder remains. So, this was a very magnetic puzzle. Too bad there were no polecats. *see for example this Feynman clip: https://youtu.be/MO0r930Sn_8?si=vPfch_asuLt0zAol
Cutting out actual words or shortening them isn't clever in my opinion.  Kind of ruins the Sunday morning NYT that I look forward to each week.

I felt so clever to enter ONT as my [Mich. neighbor]--after all, I plan to spend the afternoon at my Sister-in-Law's, in that province to our south! Too bad it was wrong. SWOLE GLAMAZON with ABS OF STEEL: a little, um, superficial? I don't know about you all, but I fight my Battles royale. Great clues for OBI and STRATO-. Speaking of the latter: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SHxwrRn-MzU&t=7s and a little closer to home: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W05A7nQ7Nzg

One more gripe, if it's not been mentioned before - seems to me the "bend" spots are unchecked squares.  If you thought, for example, a nice Chihuly would make lovely lawn ornaments, there is no way to rule out GREEN GLASS for 54 D.
Hated it.
Does anyone else feel that 55D was a bit on the nose?

Okay.
Okay.

Theme idea? Fun.
Animals with magnets between them.
Animal Magnetism.

Grid? 
Solid. 
Word count, flow, visually enticing!

Themers?
Matching??
Green grass and periwinkle.
Noodle bowl and egg foo yung.
Woah.

Fill? 
What fill?
Glamazon is just plain fun.
Do a jig.
Miltie.
Fan Fic.
Fix it in post.

Sheesh.
Kugelman nails it!

Again!

Imma go back and just look at it for a few.

Happy Sunday all!

This was too clever for me, leaving enjoyment behind I’m afraid. Oh, I completed it and found some great clues, but the overall theme held no MAGNETISM for me. I’m always sad when I can’t gel with a constructor’s work. There’s so much effort put into producing a grid that I so want to ‘get’ it.

The downside; so very many names and products unknown.

On the upside; any mention of Mr Wilde or Pooh and I’m sold.  

I always wanted to be a GLAMAZON. I picture 1930’s beauties like Ginger Rogers; sleek, svelte and able to twirl in killer heels. Sadly, I’m 5’ 4’’ and can fall over in wellies. Ah me, I can but dream.

Strands #462
“On Broadway”
🔵🔵🔵🟡
🔵🔵🔵

Timely!  :)


NO SPOILERS, please, until after the View All Replies button...

This puzzle must have been *very* challenging to construct. That said, I didn't enjoy solving it and found the theme rather underwhelming. Random three letter creatures "attached" to one another with horseshoe magnets, symbolizing ANIMALMAGNETISM. Too little bang for my buck. Especially with fill like TINGS, STEERTO, DOAJIG, LEDTO---and all those short entries needed to accommodate the theme.

Solved it unaided, but then spent more (and more enjoyable) time trying to create a thematic entry of my own. Likely I'll find a better one already in the comments, but here goes:

"Like Updike's Rabbit tetralogy" --- FOURVOLUME. Stick that in your 18D!

(The EMUs better like this comment.)

Quite a puzzle, John Kugelman! There was an extra level of mystery for me due to missing the magnet graphics, which meant that the revealer was also something of a mystery. I could see the animals but no magnetism. I was very pleasantly surprised and relieved when the gold star appeared. I’m not sure I would have had the strength to hunt for errors on this one.

For the record, dear readers, I generally solve on a rather outdated iPad. The overlay feature is turned on, but often the overlays are still missing. Usually, like today, I can finish the puzzle anyway, but I sometimes get a little cranky when I realize what wasn’t there. Hardly a life or death issue. If I weren’t a creature of habit I could solve on my phone (which displays overlays) but then I have to find my phone…

I'm not a fan of puzzles that allow gibberish in the grid. 

TEEL RATS GANT DOGF
RASS ELKN BOWL GNUY

Not elegant, in my opinion. I don't have a better suggestion, other than using words that make the bend around and also are actual words when read left-to-right - LIVE-EVIL for example.
I'm not done yet, but I have to say there are way too many blank clues.

I'm not to post this as a reply to any particular comment, because I don't want to single anyone out, but--

--it always amazes me the number of people who come on to the Wordplay comments to complain about entries like "ABSOFST"; I assume they have not completed the puzzle--maybe only just started it--and haven't picked up the gimmick yet; that's fine, but still, they would have to have clicked on the "read about today's puzzle on Wordplay" link, and then again on "read comments," to post their complaint, without ever having "read about today's puzzle"! I mean, that's a lot of effort, just to maintain one's ignorance. Poor Caitlyn:-( (et aliae).

I could copy this comment, and repost in on virtually every Sunday, and many Thursdays, changing only the details.
Another tedious Sunday gimmick. And this one was almost as much fun as digging a hole and filling it back up (gimmick-kcimmig).
This was just tickled me. I might’ve actually giggled. Thanks!

I knew there was a gimmick because of the magnets and hyphens.   But I didn't get it myself.  I filled in what I could and read the top of the column for the explanation (and stopped before I got to the examples in the column).   Then I got all the instances except ABS OF STEEL (to my shame).

Ah, yes! Yes, the true genius of the constructor is only revealed when you see how the last syllables of the surnames of the first 14 US Presidents are in direct opposition with the first syllables of the names of the last 18 British Prime Ministers. Brilliant! 

Also, when four copies of the completed puzzles are interlaced laterally, a message from the ancients will be revealed, but only to those who are worthy, who must engage transportation to the highest spot listed in 108D and deliver it to an alien deity of great substance (but little luminance) who will instantly destroy and rebuild the universe into its next evolutionary clambake. 

Oh, and 52A is N-A-U-G-H-T-Y-P-I-N-E. Ho-ho. What a clever pun.

To each his/hers/their own, I guess.
Gave up!!! too much for me...very few gimmes!!!!
Had some good, some bad and some ugly...and for me, it ulimately failed to hold it's attraction.

Nice one. The theme with lots of entries helped to slow things down at first, which I like on a Sunday. When I stumbled across the revealer clue, I only had _NI_____________ but with the magnets in the grid I managed to figure it out and get going properly on the fill. Great solve experience!
Super work, thanks John!
After spending more than 1.5 hours on this puzzle, I got undone by the northeast corner. La petite Therese? Still don’t get it. Is it STE for Saint Therese? Throws hands up.

Any puzzle that starts with Jason Momoa is fine by me, but I enjoyed this one even more as I figured out the answers that were bent by the magnets, then realized the two connected answers were related terms, and that it worked that way for all four pairs. Cool puzzle, I thought, and then I saw the revealer, and wondered what animals had to do with it. AHA! How did he do that?? Way cool!

Got the idea that the magnets were pulling the down answers around the corners right off in the NW corner working with Momoa, Statham, and Stallone. Gold star in about average Sunday time, and despite the revealer, did not twig to the animals until I read the column. 
Raise your hand if you were watching the French Open when you came to 20A?! ME!
Hmmmm...all my squares are correctly filled in, but the puzzle won't complete.  Is there a trick here?
Utterly joyless solve, too much dross and not enough mettle (see what I did there?)
The photo caption should be beaut of a puzzle.

I do so much admire the constructors and the work they do, but I wonder if too much thought goes to them and not enough to the solvers.  Too many obsolete words have to be used.  And I am one who does not hesitate to look up to finish puzzles.  I feel for those who don't.
Excellent, fun puzzle. Tough enough to occupy me for 51 pleasant minutes on a Sunday morning.
Another Sunday slog.  Magnet theme just made it clunky.

Interesting puzzle.  Took about 1.5 times the usual time.  I think my total ignorance of plants (alpines and periwinkles included) and eastern food (egg foo yung and noodle bowl included) made this especially hard.  Can someone explain the origin of "bork" as "break"?  And does it mean break as in rest or break as in fracture?
I enjoyed this one. As soon as I got the big clue and then figured out how the magnets worked, this one was a breeze. I had a fun time with it 🐾
The theme is a bit forced. Not my fave.

Really disappointing puzzle. 

Why do only 3 letters out of the 4 participate in the magnetism? Leaving those outside letters hanging doing nothing there makes no sense. 

And what exactly is it about these animals that makes them pair up and attract one another? DOG and ANT. Just nonsensical. 

I kept going, waiting for some elegance and ingenuity in the theme to reveal itself, and it never did.

Can I just say as someone who grew up in a German speaking country that the answer to  ‘A, in German class’ is wrong. I applaud the appearance of DAEMONS in today's puzzle.  
Socrates claimed that he had a personal DAEMON, a divine voice that spoke to him and kept him from doing things he shouldn't.  Some see this as an ancestor of the concept of "conscience", a concept that doesn't exist in Ancient Greek.  Most agree that this is the reason he was charged with "introducing new Gods" into the city of Athens.

The word is also indicative of the way that Christianity "d[a]emonizes" the Gods of other religions.

Back to old times with this one! Took me the time Sundays used to take, over an hour. (When I first started these, might have taken me a few days over an hour.) No lookups, but for awhile, thought I was going to have to look up the preservative. 

Love that it required going back to the theme to find my letter amiss. That square was _only_ checked by the theme, and discoverable only after reviewing my theme answers and noticing yet another theme symmetry, and seeing that my answer violated it. 

I had thought the four letters to the right of each set of magnets had been scrambled to pull the 3-letter animal to the magnet. But now I could see they were not scrambled, but cleanly bent toward the magnet. Except for one. Although I did realize ACTIONaToR did not make a heck of a lot of sense. Unless it was some kind of homage to The Terminator, which as far as I knew, Stallone had not appeared in. (Had no idea about Statham.)

At this point, it was clear I just needed to read those last four letters in (backwards) order to make sense of 9D, and the incorrect letter was obvious. Done.

Feeling pretty good about myself, I read the column and then discovered there was yet _another_ level of theme symmetry I had not seen--the paired downs. 

Kugelman, I bow to you.

@Peter
There are three noun genders in german:  male, female and neutral.
In the nominative case "Ein" ("A") modifies the male and neutral nouns.
"Eine" modifies the feminine.
And "Eins" is the number one.

@Francis

It boils down to how large a wheelhouse one has.  If it is small, some puzzles will be OBI (that is, it's a cinch!) and some will make you shout that the cluing is bad.

The expression "in one's wheelhouse" is common in baseball, meaning that the pitcher threw the ball in a spot from which the batter does well hitting.  So you learn to pitch Pete Alonso away from a certain part of the strike zone, but maybe you pitch Aaron Judge away from a different part.  Players who have a larger wheelhouse get more hits.  So it is with crosswords.

Ultimately, crosswords favor those with a large knowledge base, both popular and academic, and the ability to see things from various angles.  (See Peter's adjacent comment.)

And, of course, an understanding of polysemy.

@Andrzej

A strike zone is the area above home plate and basically aligned with the middle of the batter’s body, height-wise, where the ball must be hit, or it will be called a strike (three strikes and you’re out). Pitchers pitch to a certain part of the zone if they are skillful enough to do so, but different batters are more proficient in certain parts of the zone. But of course, the better batters are proficient over a larger part of the strike zone. 

Pitching away means pitching to the farthest corners of the zone (as seen by the batter) or even a bit outside the zone in order to entice the batter to swing at balls he doesn’t have a good chance of hitting. Pitching a batter in or inside is just the opposite. Batters with a bigger wheelhouse are harder to pitch to. 

Crossword solvers with a bigger wheelhouse are harder to trick.
